div.head: THE CALIPHATE.
div.p: An interesting point has been raised by Canon McColl, who maintains that the Sultan of Turkey is not, and never has been, Caliph; that the spiritual power is rested solely in the Sheik-ul-Islam. The importance of the point exists in the fact that were the Sultan truly Caliph Mohammedans in every country would be compelled to obey his orders and fight against their rulers. Canon McColl's assertion is sup- ported by the fact that when Abdul Hamid inaugurated his great Pan Islamic crusade, although some success was won among lesser tribes, the Sultans of Morooco and Zanzibar laughed to scorn the emissaries of the "Shadow of God" and "Refuge of the World"—by which unassuming titles the Sultan is known. The supreme spiritual head of the Church in Turkey is the Sheik-ul-Islam. The relations between himself and the Saltan are of a com- plicated, even grimly ludicrous, character, unparalleled throughout the world.

The Caliph must be of the Prophet's tribe, but that distinction cannot be claimed for the Sultan. Seeing that mothers of Turkish Sultans, are almost insatiably slaves, there is very, little but plebeian blood left in the Turkish royal family. Still, heir he is born, and, with miraculous luck, Sultan he becomes. As such it is his privilege to lay hands upon the relics, of Mohamed. This the Sheik-ul-Islam may not do. Now, the Sultan nominates, and may depose, the Sheik-ul-Islam. But this is a re- ciprocal arrangement, for if the Sultanamiable subjects determine to murder or other- wise efface their lord they may not do so until the formal written permission of the Sheik-ul-Islam has been given. Moreover, if he wishes to make any appeal to the Faithful, he must so appeal through this potent priset. Without the consent of the letter he cannot promulgate any new dogma, neither can he alter any item of the Islamic ritual. He must have this high dignitary about him, and must appoint him; but, having made the appoint- ment, he has set up his own master and given into his hands the mastery of hie life and death.

div.head:
RUSSIAN REVOLUTION.
ANTI-GOVERNMENT COMBINE.
MILITARY TERRORISTS.

div.p: All the revolutionary organizations have com- bined in one solid anti-government body. (R.)

A military terrorist organisation has been discovered which bad for its aim the extermi- nation of all authorities and the co-operation of all revolutionaries. Fourteen officers have been arrested. (Reuter)
Al Ukase has summoned General Stoessel to court-martial (Havas)

The "Daily Mail" has published the account of an interview with Prince von Buelow, who is reported to have repudiated the idea that Germany thinks of competing with England for the mastery of the sea; her object was merely commercial rivalry. He declared that Germany's interests in Persia and the Bagdad railway were purely commercial. The King and the Emperor William at their recent meeting did not discuss acute political ques- tions, as such did not exist between England and Germany. The meeting marked an suspi- cions stage on the road to the elimination of misunderstandings. (Reuter)

div.head:
MR. HALDANE IN BERLIN.
LUNCH WITH KAISER.

div.p: Mr. Haldane lunched with the Emperor William and subsequently bad a lengthy interview with the Minister of Foreign Affairs. (Reuter)
Lord Elgin has sent to the Governor a congratulatory message appreciating the cou- rage and self-restraint with which the recent emergencies were met. (Reuter)
The battleship Lord Nelson has been launched at Yarrow. (Reuter)
General French and the other English officers attending the maneuvres were greatly privi- leged, being the only foreign officers admitted to the deliberations of the umpires. (Reuter)

div.head:
FRANCE'S RELIGIOUS CRISIS.
EPISCOPACY AND POPE

div.p: The bishops have held an important confer- ence to consider their attitude to the question of public worship, in conflict between the Pope, and the French Government (Reuter)
A plenary meeting of the French Episcopacy was held this morning and sent to the Pope a telegram of filial obedience. (Havas)

div.head: MALTESE INFANT MORTALITY.
div.p: Many persons begin to be appalled by the infant mortality of Malta. They give expres- sion to their alarm and anxiety in the local newspapers, particularly in the Italian section of them. It is not clear how the frightful loss of infant lives is caused nor how it can be lessened. Official statistics just published show the general death-rate to have been for the last governmental year 26 per 1,000 of the population, whereas children under one year have perished at the rate of 244 for every 1,000 born. The death rate of children under five years of age ascends to 53 per cent. of the general death-rate.

div.head: AMERICAN INSURANCE SCANDALS.
div.p: The international policyholders' committee, according to the "New York Tribune," is beginning an investigation in France, Germany, and Great Britain to discover whether the Mutual Life and the New York have violated the law by tailing to file policyhol- dress' movement in these countries that they have been unable to obtain proper lists.

div.head: Jedivial Law School.
div.p: The maximum of students admitted is 150; applicants must have a degree, in order to (unclear)ter.

div.head: The Wakfs.
div.p: On his return from Europe Adly Pasha eghen intends making great changes in the Wakfs Administration, to include the staff.
The Pyramid Road.
The drainage works on the Pyramid road have not yet been taken in hand seriously and of the credit of L. E. 3,986 for the enterprise L. E. 34 have been spent as yet.
New Land Company.
It is rumoured that a financial company was recently founded in London for the pur- pose of purchasing the estates of Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel at Ghizeh.
Esbekleh Cardens Theatre
We would remind our readers that M. Louis Gardet's comedy company makes its début at the Esbskieh Gardens Theatre, Cairo, to-night with the well known French play Le Monde où oil ne s'ennuie pas
MoJouan Markaz Court

The Ministry of Justice has issued an order to the effect that the sittings of the Helonan Marhaz Court should be held on the second and fourth Saturdays of every month, instead of Sundays. The new arrangement came into effect on the 1st inst.
Boxing.

In connection with the Regimental Novices Boxing Competition which will be held at the Citadel about the 20th inst., there will be three contests open to the Garrison. Entries close on the 10th inst. For particulars apply to President, Boxing Club, 1st Bn. Lancashire Fusiliers.
A Postal Scandal.

In the course of an enquiry made at Mahalla Kebir Post Office, the house of a postman has been searched and a number of letters found, which, it appears, the postman had hidden instead of delivering. The letters have been forwarded to their destination,and the postman placed under arrest.
The First Egyptian Date.

Professor James H. Breasted, Egyptologist of the University of Chicago, has announced, in an article in the "Biblical World" that the oldest fixed date in history is 4241 B.C. The professor says the calendar was established in that year, and that the year began on what would now be July 19. He bases his assertion upon recent investigations in Egypt.
Cairo Cambling Dens.

A raid was made upon an Italian gaming house in the Esbekieh quarter of Cairo on Monday night. An Italian janissary waited outside the building and, on the dispute of the proprietor that the police were not entitled to enter his house without Consular authority, speedily convinced the man that the raid was fully authorised. The stakes and perquisites of the baccarat table were seized.
Mudir's Motor Mishap.

The President of the Shoubra Summary Court yesterday sentenced the chauffeur of the motor car wherein the Mudir of Keneh came to grief recently, to four months' im- prisonment. Reports from Keneh state that Yessin Bey Mustapha, the Mudir, is can- celling the leave which he has been granted owing to his recent accident. His health is improving rapidly and he will arrive at Keneh in a week to take over his duties.
Mission School at Luxor.

It may interest oar readers to know some- thing about the new American Mission School at Luxor. It is a very large one, capable of accommodating 5OO girl boarders. The building, which cost about £9.000, is now nearly com- plete, and it is considered the best structure of its kind in Egypt. It is unique too in being erected upon the avenue of sphinxes leading from the sacred temple at Karnac to the temple at Luxor. Such a school should prove a great blessing to Upper Egypt, not only for its strictly educational value, but also because it is training so many native girls to become good wives and mothers. It is very fortunate in possessing such an ex- cellent Head Mistress as Miss Buchanan, who is a cultivated and large-minded woman with her heart in the work, and is aided by a good staff of teachers. The School will open on Wednesday, September 5th, when the au- tumn term begins.
School of Medicine

With a view be placing the study of science on a better footing the Ministry of Public Instruction so long ago as July, 1905, present- ed s note to the Council of Ministers recom- mending the division into scientific and literary sections of the State secondary schools, so that students could follow more successfully the particular branch of study of their choice. On Sunday 55 bachelors of science and 28 bachelors of letters applied to the Khedivial school of Medicine, for admission. The Director informed them, however, that by a letter of from the Ministry of Public Instruction, not more than 40 bachelors of science could be admitted at a time, so that the superfluous 15 would have to call again on Saturday, to be listed. Regarding the bachelors of letters, the Director regretted his inability to accept them, and advised them to go and study medicine in England, whence they would be officially recommended to the Egyptian Ministry of Public Instruction. Our friend the "Moayad" begs the Government to enter the 15 bachelors of science to the Polytechnic School.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
ARRIVAL AT VIENNA.
div.p: A Havas telegram from Vienna this morning announces that the Khedive has arrived at the Austrian Capital.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: Leave of absence has boon granted to El Miralai Selim Bey Mossali, disponibilité, until November 18; to El Kaimakam Townsend Bey, A.A.G , until November 11; and to El Bimbashi Coningham. assistant Director of Surveys, until November 13.
Lieutenant W. F. Stirling, D.S.O., Royal Dublin Fusiliers., has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bim- bashi and is posted to the Khartoum district.

div.head: BRITISH SOLDIERS ATTACKED.
div.p: It is reported that an attack was made on two British officers of the Army of Occupa- tion in the Abdin district of Cairo on Monday night by three Greek sobjects. A police officer, accompanied by shawishes, speedily arrived on the scene of the affray, hot experienced considerable trouble in quelling the disturbance which was caused, and only succeeded in arresting two of the three men, who were intoxicated. In the course of the disturbance a gas pipe was broken and a fire broke out, but was speedily extinguished.

So runs the report. We do not intend, however, to state these as the exact details of the case, which we hold over for confirma- tion. We are informed by the Ministry of the Interior that two British soldiers were attacked on that night, but at the time of our inquiries they were unable to give us any particulars of the affray, or state whether the victims were officers or privates. We also made enquiries at the Cairo Headquarters of the Army of Occupation and received as a reply that we were the first to have given that office any information of an attack having occurred.
The following is the version of the "Journal da Caire" :

On Monday evening the police officer of Abdin district was informed that three natives, in a state of intoxication, had seriously assault- ed two British officers in the midan of the Opera. On arrival on this square, he found three persons striking the shawishies who were holding them. After a lively resistance he took them to the caracol. While the officer was drawing op the procès verbal, one of the assailants Alexander Kodsi, snatched it from him and tore it up, and at the same time, G. Arakgi upset the writing table on the officer, and wounded him. The third attacked the shawishes and hit them repeatedly. The three ruffians were overpowered, however, and con- fined. Soon afterwards a fire broke oat owing to the carrying away of the gas-pipe in the prison. The shawishes promptly put the fire out. The enquiry has found these ruffians to be Greeks, of evil antecedents.

div.head: AN ECHO OF DENISHWAI
div.p: "Al Minbar" remarks :—

One of the passengers who arrived by the German steamer from Europe informs us that Ibrahim Helbawi Bey. on embarking on the that steamer, came to greet Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha, who was among the passengers. The brother of His Highness the Khedive is beloved by the Egyptians and the "Young Egyp- tian Party" for his energy and patriotism. His conversation with M. deGuerville published in the latter's book is still in the minds of all and fully proves his sincere patriotism. When Helbawi Bey draw near the Prince to greet him His Highness refused to hold out his hand to him, and addressed to him some painful and wounding words, which we will refrain from mentioning. When His Highness was asked by the Captain of the steamer as to the gentlemen whom he would invite to his table, Prince Mohamrd Aly replied "all the Egyptian passengers except one named Helbawi." Such is the Prince's patriotism, which is a good lesson. The existence of such a spirit in our princes and leaders is welcome.

div.head: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH ALTERATION.
div.p: The plastering and repairing of the interior of All Saints' Church is making good progress, but owing to a certain amount of delay in commencing operations there is little likeli- hood of the work being finished before the end of the month. So long as the work is in hand it is impossible to hold the accustomed services on Fridays and Saints' days, conse- quently in the calendar they have bean omit- ted, but should the repairs be completed before the close of September, these services will, of course, be at once resumed. Notice of their resumption will be given out at the Sunday services and printed in General Orders.

The services on the last three Sundays in August have been held in the Boulac Chapel and North Aisle. The organ it rather far away from the choir, and this adds somewhat to the difficulties of a choir, reduced in num- bers, and of Mr. Mackintosh, the new organist, but they have successfully triumphed over these difficulties, while the compactness of the congregation has made the service more hearty and the attendance to appear larger than usual. Mr. Roddam, who bas been such a pillar of strength to the choir, both in the regularity of his attendances at services and practices and in the never failing power of his voice, has left for three months, having gone to England on leave. He carries with him the good wishes of all who know him for a very happy holiday.

div.head: WALKER & MEIMARACHI, LTD.
MR. MEIMARACHI'S POSITION.
div.p: The rumour of Mr. Constantine Meimarachi's resignation of the Managing Directorship of Walker and Meimarachi Limited has created considerable stir locally, for that gentleman commanded the confidence of the shareholders, and was generally regarded as the moving spirit of the Company. All sorts and kinds of reports have been afloat as to whether he had or had not resigned, and many and various have been the reasons given for this step. On the other hand, the "Phare d'Alexandrie" on Monday stated that the differences between Mr. Meimarachi and the London Board had been settled and that consequently the resignation had been withdrawn. We regret to state that our contemporary's optimistic statements are inexact. Mr. Meimarachi is at present in France with his family, and will only go to London in the middle of this month, when the Board of Directors will hold a meeting. At this meeting Mr. Meimara. chi will present his report on the working of the Company during the past year. At this meeting the Board of Directors will discuss the question of the construction of the new Cairo stores. In case the Board refuses to sanction Mr. Meimarachi's plans and programme he will send in his resignation. It is sincerely to be hoped that the Board will approve all Mr. Meimarachi's plans and will give him a free hand to do his utmost for the development of the Company, whose welfare he has so sincerely at heart. But assuming that the contrary happens, and that Mr. Meimarachi finds that he is obliged to tender his resignation, we presume that a general meeting of the shareholders of the company will be convened in Egypt, for no less than seven-eighths of the total shares are held at Cairo and Alexandria and almost all the shares are in the hands of friends and acquaintances of Mr. Meimarachi. Possibly therefore the shareholders will demand that the London Board should be done away with. That board costs the shareholders about £2,000 a year and there does not appear to be any valid reason for its existence, as, in our opinion, the best site for the Board is at Cain, the London Board being really a superfluous luxury.

div.head: BUILDING LANDS OF EGYPT.
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the above company was held at Alexandria yester- day, the 4th inst., at the Company's Offices. There was a large gathering of shareholder, 29,559 shares being represented.

The meeting, after having heard the Report of the Board of Directors, and having been informed that Me. Glymenopoulo had been persuaded to abandon the commission origi- nally claimed by him, and also taking into consideration the protest of the Company's auditor concerning the previous meetings, declared that the resolutions voted on at the meetings of the 26th Jane and 18th July are of no effect and will now be voted as follows:—

The meeting approved of the amalgamation of the Building Lands of Egypt with the Egyptian Trust and Investment Limited by the absorption of the latter Company, and on the conditions indicated in the agreement of the 2nd June, 1906, made between the boards of the two Companies.

The meeting decided to increase the capital of the Company by the issue of 60,000 shares of £4 to bear rank "pari passu" with those already issued. These 60,000 shares will be delivered to the Shareholders of the Egyptian Trust and Investment Limited in exchange for the 200,000 shares folly paid, at the rate 3 Buildings for 10 Trusts.
Every power is given to the Board to carry out the amalgamation on the lines set forth in the preceding paragraphs.
Messrs Cumbo and Lombardo are appointed directors.
All other resolutions voted by the two meet- ings of the 26th June and 18th July are cancelled.

div.head: THE YEMEN.
div.p: The two transports bought by the Turkish Government in England have left Smyrna with 3,000 recruits on board for the Yemen. It appears that a disturbance broke out on board one of the vessels, the men objecting to going to the Yemen, but the movement was repressed without difficulty, and the vessels continued on their voyage. Two transports arrived at Kavak some days ago with recruits from Black Sea ports also bound for the Yemen, bat they mu- tinied and seized and bound their officers, refusing at all costs to go to the Yemen, whence they declared none of their comrades had ever returned. They were willing to die for the Sultan in any other part of the Empire but not the Yemen. An aide de-camp from the Sultan was sent on board and after some nego- tiation the men received assurances that they would not be required to continue their voyage. They immediately released their offi- cers and were subsequently landed in Constan- tinople were they have been enrolled in the regiments of the garrison.

div.head: QUARANTINE
div.p: A telegram from Pera this morning announ- ces that arrivals from Alexandria and Suez will have to undergo 24 hours' quarantine, disinfection, and deratisation.
The measures against arrivals from Port Said have been suppressed.
Arrivals from Adalia and Trebizond have to undergo disinfection and deratisation.

div.head: SUAKIN NOTES.
SUAKIN-ATBARA LINE.
TRAFFIC STOPPED BY WASHOUTS.
div.p: Suakio, Angnst 29.

Terrible washouts have again occurred in several places, and the line has been inter- rupted now 1er over a month. Several bridges will have to be added to the Suakin-Atbara line so as to allow a free passage of the water, which come down in torrents over 1,000 feet wide and about 8 to 10 feet deep. The Khors are far too wide for a few bridges of 100 feet span, so that now the rush of water with its full force is bound to wash away the earth- banks adjoining the bridges. Of course these large washouts were not foreseen when the line was in construction as this year's wash- outs are the biggest seen for many years. The soldiers and Berbereen labourers are working very hard under the supervision of Bimbashis Newcombe and Lord to make new embank- ments where the lines have been washed out. The force of the water was so strong that it washed away heavy iron girders and huge rocks for a distance of a few kilometres. The British steamer "Langdale" arrived here from England on the 25th inst., with a large consignment of railway material for the Sudan Government Railways, including 11,000 bags of cement and 10 bridges.

The Rev. Blackledge, Army Chaplain, Church of England, passed through here en route for Khartoum, and held Divine Service in the Suskin Moudirieh chapel on Sunday, the 26th inst; he was as listed by Bimbashi Newcombe, R.E., Agent to the Railways at Suakin. There was a fair attendance of Englishmen in spite of the summer holidays.
Mr. Wilfrid Lord, brother of Bimbashi Lord, R.E., has arrived from England, and taken up an appointment with the Works Department at Port Sudan.

Mr. C.M. Heckley, engineer to the Sudan Government Railways, has returned from leave of absence, and will relieve Bimbashi New- combe, R.E. as Agent to the Sudan Govern- ment Railways at Suakin, who is going on leave in a few days. Mr. Sniarl, Assistant Loco Superintendent, Sudan Government Rail- ways, has also gone on leave to England, and Mr. Bonici, District Locomotive Superinten- dent, will act for Mr. Sniarl daring his absence.

Mr. W.H. Bailey, Inspector of Bridges, contracted a slight sunstroke while oat on the washouts at Kamaksana, which compelled him to be under medical treatment for some days. He has now resumed work once more and is out of danger.

div.head: ITALIAN SILK IN EGYPT.
div.p: Italy is greatly improving her commerce with Egypt, especially in silk. She is now on a level with France in her exportation of silk into Egypt, and even the French Chamber of Commerce in Alexandria foresees that Italy will be the entire mistress of the silk trade in Egypt. One reason for this is that Italian silk is cheaper and lighter than French silk. One quality especially, called "silk zephyr," which has recently been launched on the Alexandria market has met with the greatest favour. It is made plain, striped, figured and embroi- dered in open work. Its price varies from 1 1/2f to 2 1/2f It is a lovely material for ladies' blouses for summer, as well as for Orientals to wear. It ought to be a success on the English market.

div.head: THE TEACHING FACULTY.
div.p: The following are extracts from the report of the Commission appointed to examine fikths (school masters) and arifs (oshera) :— Out of 1,325 candidates, 327 fikihs and 241 arifs passed the examination ; of these six were fikieh and six arifeh, or lady teachers, who were granted diplomas.
The normal schools for the preparation of teachers are that of Abdul Aziz, founded in 1904, that of the Fayoum in 1905, and that of Boulac, for lady teachers, in 1903.
The number of inspectors and assistant inspectors last year was 38.
Certificates were awarded to 1,356 teachers, of whom 682 were fikihs, 674 arif, 19 fikihieh and 18 arifeh. Seven were Christians.

div.head: NEW VICTORIA HOTEL.
div.p: The following visitors are staying at the New Victoria Hotel. Ramleh : Mr. and Mrs. Helbaboui Bey and family, Mr. A. N. Arif, Mr. and Mrs. G. Arif and family. Mr. H. Wynne, Dr. Const. Jeannacopoulos and family, Miss Pappa, Mr. and Mrs. A. Sednaoui, Judge Josef Bey Soliman, Mr. H. A. El Taoudis, Advocate Abdel Latif Mikabbady, Mr. Fathy Bey, Mr. a nd Mrs. Oscar Gantes and family. Dr. Ahmed Aly, Mr. and Mrs. A. Khoury Haddad and family, Mr. Isaac Rofé, Mr. and Mrs. Josef Naggiar and family, Mr. Maurice Talamas, Mr. and Mrs. Talamas Bey, the Visses Zana- niri, Advocate E. Zananiri, Mme Vve P. Zana- niri. Mme Josef Zananiri, Mr. G. Zahar, Dr. S.M. Sameh Bey and family, Mr. and Mrs. N. Soussa, Dr. Schemeil and family, Mr. F. Zalzil, Prof. Dr. Portugalis Bey, Mr. and Mrs. A. Azoury Bey, Mr. and Mrs. Josef Saheb Bey, Mme Vve. Nahas Bey, the Misses Nahas, Mr. J Montrau, Mr. N. Yazbeck.

div.head: NOTES FROM BEYROUT.
NEW DRAINAGE SCHEME.
AN ELECTRIC TRAMWAY-
div.p: Beyrout, August 27.

The drainage scheme to which I referred in my last notes is beginning to crystallize into palpable shape. The Monicipality is now buildiog at the end of the Damascus road, which opens into the Square, a few meters of subterranean vaulted sewer of solid masonry, by way of trial, in order to determine the pre- cise cost per meter, and thus be in a position to properly assess the properties on both sides of the roads through which the sewers are proposed to be made. I had mentioned that the rate of contribution, according to which the Municipality had called upon the proprie- tors to subscribe, was fixed at 100 piastres per meter; I am now informed by the Mayor, who has the credit of being the initiator of this excellent scheme, that simultaneously with the construction of the sewers the laying of paved sidewalks will be undertaken, and the rate of construction is estimated to amount then to L.T. 2 per meter of built property. This up-to-date system of covered sewerage will incalculably improve the sanitation of the town. The fact of Beyrout being built on a n atural amphitheatre will, by the rather steep inclination of most of the roads, constitute in itself a great source of economy. The sidewalks prove another boon to the inhabitants. The promiscuity of traffic in the streets of Beyrout is as ludicrous as it is revolting. Carriages, cars, trucks, uncouth camels with bulky and obstructive burdens, mules and donkeys with equally cumbersome loads, and riders of horses, mulee, and donkeys, share with the poor pedes- train the limited space of our streets. Indeed the human species has the worst part of the road, and to cap his miseries, lounging, idle, dirty dogs beset his path, and would resent with a growl or a snarl any summary request en the part of the passer-by to make way. But, great as is this nuisance of dogs, it has i ts good side, and I, for one, believe that without these energetic scavengers heaps of fermenting domestic refuse would fill the atmosphere of the town with noxious exhalations. These scavengers perform their duty at least more conscientiously than their paid biped collea- gues of the Municipality.
Electric Tramway.

The people of Beyrout are awaiting with great anxiety the beginnings of this important scheme, which is not only calculated to bring about a better condition of the roads, and develop the town in different ways, but will also deliver people of modest means from the unrestrained insolence and tyranny of carriage- drivers. It had been said that the Company's engineer was to return here in October next, to start the work forthwith. I have been in- formed by the President of the Municipality that he recently received a telegram from the engineer advising him of his arrival at Brussels, and adding that he was forwarding particulars by letter. Although things in the East are apt to evolve rather slowly, yet in this instance the fact of the Electric Tramway Company having already bought some land at the outskirts of the town for the erection of its depot station is an earnest of the accomplishmennt of the scheme.
An American Horse Collector.

The famous American cartoonist, Mr. Homer Davenport, arrived here lately with two wealthy Americans enamoured of sport and travel. Mr. Davenport has for his main object in this visit the purchase of the best Arab breds. He has unfortunately been forestalled by a party of Italians, who last week sailed by the Florio Rubattino steamer with the finest specimens of Arab bred horses, destined for the Italian Royal studs. It is said, however, that a large tribe of about 1,400 Bedouins have migrated lately from the Northern re- gions between the Tigris and Euphrates to the plains of Hama and Homs, with all their cattle and horses, and this may afford this American horse collector an exceptional oppor- tunity to come across some fine specimens, without having to travel extensively in the interior and lose much time and money. In the meantime these three travellers are having extra fine sport in the bountiful regions around Alexandretta and Antioch, and they are said to be provided with rifles of the most perfect- ed type, mounted with small telescopes for long distance shooting. I hear from the American Consul that Mr. Davenport is ex- pected back here in about a fortnight, and that be intends giving a lecture on cartooning, which he may be illustrating with extempore rough cartoons on a screen ad hoc. This would certainly be a rare occasion.
U.S. Vice-Consul.

Mr. Megelsen, United States Vice-Consul, who is acting for the Consul General, pending the arrival of Mr G. Bie Ravndal, has been appointed Consul at Baghdad. While his friends are pleased at this promotion, yet they, and, indeed many of the Beyroutines, will regret the departure of a capable gentle man who has lived so many years in this country and taken such an intelligent interest in its economic development.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Marquis di Soragna, Italian Consul at Cairo, arrived at Alexandria last night from the Capita1, and will leave to morrow for Italy by the Floric Rubattino steamer.
Sir Rudolph Slatin Pasha, Inspector General of the Sudan, was received in private audience last week by the King at Marienbad.
Lady McIlwraith has booked her return passage to Egypt by the P. & O. S.S. Egypt, which leaves London on the 19th proxo.
Scandar Pasha Fehmy is returning to Egypt by the P. & O. S.S Persia, which leaves London on the 21st inst.
Mr. Abdy, who is staying at Vevey, is arriving at Alexandria on the 17ch iust. by the Anstrian Lloyd steamer from Trieste.
Among the passengers arriving at Port Said by the P. & O. S.S. Arcadia, which left Mar- seilles last Friday, are Mr. and Mrs, G. Scott- Dalgleisb, Aly BeyTimour, Mr. Beadnell, and Mustapha Kamel Bey.
G. Nungovich Bey and Mr. Klingler, ex- manager of the Continental Hotel and now appointed to Mena House, have arrived in Cairo.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit -within certain necessary limits— free discussion.

div.head: TINNED FOODS AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—Are the Alexandria City Police or the Manicipality making any attempt to prevent the public health being injured by tinned and canned foods? After the shocking revelations of American methods, as given in "The Jun- gle," surely the authorities in Egypt ought to take some measures to protect the public. I noticed the following paragraph in the latest English newspapers:—

"At a meeting of the Devon Standing Joint Committee the Chief Constable (Mr. F.R.C. Coleridge) reported that during the three months ended July 31 the police, acting as inspectors under the Food and Drags Act, took forty samples of tidied, canned, and potted meats. He regretted to say that grave fault had been found with those of foreign brands, the county analyst having in some cases certified the contents of tins to be unfit for human consumption. He suggested that the Committee, in the interest of the public, might think right to authorise him to issue some warning on the subject"
This is the way the authorities should act here in the imperative interests of public health. Truly yours
"SANITAS."
Alexandria, 4th September.

div.head: GAMBLING IN EGYPT.
div.p: To the Editor op the "Egyptian Gazette".

Sir,—In one of the native papers I have recently read a article about an aggressive war against some of the police officials when raiding a gambling den, in Cairo, and how the proprietors of that hell brought untamed dogs to attack the raiders.

By chance, after reading that article. I took the "Review of Reviews, where I found that in Australia, most aggressive wars are occurring against the authority. Two paragraphs quoted here will show how the officials when raiding are met:—

(1) "In four successive cases, detectives and witnesses who had been active against gam- bling were set upon in the dark, brutally ill used and left sensless, or attacked in their own homes by bombs."

(2) "The thing is a nest of scoundrels, a den of thieves, saturating the community with a gambling spirit, and not content with that, carrying an aggressive war of evil against constituted authority."

Very glad to say that such attacks in Egypt are not known, but in course of time, we may think it possible that the gamblers and the directors of the gambling dens, when more oppressed and annoyed, will do the same.
Let us wait,
An Egyptian.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
Lu Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 4 septembre 5 heures p m. sous la présidence de M. le Dr Sohiesa Pacha.
Présents : MM. J. Barbaza, Abani Bey, Amb. A. Ralli, Q. Zervudachi, membres, A. Wilner, secrétaire p.i.
La Délégation autorise le renouvellement de l'occupatioan du Kiosque de la Compagnie de Ramleh, à la gare de Ramleh, aux mêmes con- ditions que précédemment.

Elle renvoie au rapport des services les offres présentées par divers pour 1 les travaux de dallage des rues Eba Tonloon et Cheik el Léssi, 2 de pavage de diverses ruelles, 3 de terrasse- ment de la rue Sidi Metuali, 4 de construction d'égouts à loud perdu à l'Ibrahimieh et à Bul- keley, 5 de fourniture d'un rouleau compres- seur.
Communication est donnés d'une lettre mi- nistérielle indiquant les mesures provisoires à prendre pour l'introduction de la viande con- gelée.
Ces mesures sont les suivantes:
1° Aucune viande frigorifiée ne devra être mise en vente qu'apièi avoir été soumise à l'examen du vétérinaire municipal.
Un timbre spécial sera apposé sur les viandes reconnues propres à la consommation.
2° Les débitants devront être tonus d'indi- quer par une enseigne apparente qu'ils font commerce de viande frigorifiée et d'avoir un étal séparé pour le débit de cette viande.
3° Les dépositaires et débitants devront se soumettre à tontes visites que les agents sani- taires feront dans les locaux de séjour on de débit de la viande congelée.
La Délégation en prend note.
La Délégation autorise un crédit supplé- mentaire de L.B. 60 poor la pose des plaques du recensement.
Elle proposera à la Commission l'ouverture d'un crédit supplémentaire de L.E. 60 pour les besoinsdu service vétérinaire
La Délégation sjourne à la prochaine séance l'examen do rapport de M. Piot Boy relatif à la construction de marchés en ville.
Elle prend note d'nne lettre de la Compagnie des Eaux donnant les motifs poor lesquels l'eau debitéa en ville était trouble pendant ces derniers temps.

Cet état est dù au changement rapide et imprévu de l'eau brute du canal, à la suite de la nouvelle crue. Une quantité d'alun plus con- sidérable a été employée pour purifier l'eau, qui actuellement a repris sa limpidité.
Il y a lieu de remarquer que malgré cet état trouble, les analyses n'ont rien signalé d'anor- mal relativement à la qualité de l'eau au point de vue hygiénique.

La Délégation prend note de l'état des recettes municipales qui se sont élevées du ler janvier au 31 août 1906 à LE. 154,558 pour le bndgot ordinaire et à L.E. 113,957 pour le budget extraordinaire, comprenant L.E. 79,748, reliquat de l'exercice 1905 et L.E. 34 209, recettes de cette année.
Les dépenses ont été de L.E. 119,342 pour le budget ordinaire et de L.E. 103,669 enga- gées par le budget extraordinaire, sur lesquelles 35,375 ont été effect nées.
La séance est levée à 7 h. 1/2.

div.head: AU TRIBUNAL MIXTE DU CAIRE
div.p: Le juge des référés du Tribunal mixte du Caire était appelé à rendre un jugement dans une affaire très délicate. Une de nos plus jolies et spirituelles mondaines, Mme X., qui se trouve actuellement en villégiature à San Stefano, a été assignée par on médecin den- tiste très connu de notre ville. M. W., qui lui avait prêté ses soins. La belle défenderesse déclare que le traitement imposé par le den- tiste lui causait de si vives souffrances qu'elle n'a pu le continuer. Le médecin prétend que ce n'est que par caprice que sa gentille cliente n'a pas continué le traitement, ce dernier étant conforme aux rigoureux enseignements de la science.
Maltre Merzbach, le sympathique substitut de Mtre Carton de Wiart, occupait pour M. W., Mtre Fatica pour Mme X.
M. Vasquez, juge des référés, a rendu sa- medi son ordonnance, tort bien motivée, et a déclaré n'y avoir lien ni à référé, ni `a exper- tise, et a condamné le docteur aux frais.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

La bonne tendance de ces derniers jours n'est plus. Ce matin beaucoup de valeurs réactionnent, les uns disent par suite de réali- sations de profits et les autres de ventes `a dé- couvert Ce qui semblerait donner raison à ces derniers, c'est -que le terme ne se vend guère plus cher que le comptant.
Parmi les titres qui montrent du soutien il faut citer l'Agricole qui est ferme à 9 23/32, la Delta Light à 11 3/4 et la Cassa di Sconto à 226.
En revanche, la National Bank perd 3/16 à 26 1/2, les Nnugovich Hotels 1/4 à 17 9/16 et le Comptoir 1/32 à 6 11/16 l'ancienne et 6 17/32 la nouvelle.
Les affaires n'ont pas d'ailleurs eu beaucoup d'importance.
La tendance demeura indécise.

A l'assemblée générale extraordinaire de la Buildiog Lands of Egypt, tenue hier, un grand nombre d'actionnaires assistaient. 29,559 ac- tions étaient représentées. M. Glymenopoulo abandonnant sa commission, la fusion de la so ciété avec l'Egyptian Trust and Investment a été approuvée aux conditions contenues dans l'accord du 2 juin. C'est la Building qui absorbe le Trust sur la base de 3 Building pour 10 Trust. A cet effet, le capital de la Building Lands of Egypt va être augmenté de 240,000 livres par l'émission de 60,000 actions de £4 qui seront attribués aux porteurs de Trust. Tontes les décisions prises aux assemblées pré- cédentes du 26 juin et 18 juillet sont annulées.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
div.p: Le Caire, 4 Septembre.

A Londres, le Consolidé a été coté hier 87 1/8 ex-coupon. L'Unifiéa est restée invariée à 104 3/4. La National Bank a gagné 3/8 de livre à 26 3/4. L'Agricole est demeurée inchan- gée à 9 7/8, de même que la Delta Light à 11 3/4. La Daira a perdu 1/8 à 16 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier égyptien a réactionné de 2 francs à 760. La Barque d'A- thènes est roestée stationnaire à 141.

Notre marché des valours a manifesté ce matin une plus vive animation et de meilleu- res dispositions qu'hier; mais une petite réac- tion, amenée par dus réalisations s'est produite vers la clôture. Les cours rout toutefois restés généralement soutenus.

La National Bank, que nous avions laistéè hier à 26 7/16 1/2, a débuté à 26 5/8 11/16 pour c'ourer à ce prix. L'Agricole a été égale- ment bieu tenue à 9 3/4-13/16. L'action nou- velle de la Cassa di Sconto s'est inscrite à 219- 220. Le Comptoir Financier a été poussé à 6 3/4 l'action ancienne et 6 9/16-5/8 la nouvelle.
Le Crédit Foncier a commencé à 761 pour finir à 759-760.
L'Action Immobilière a été ramenée à 390 et la part de fondateur à 740-745.
L'action Enterprise and Development a avancé à 12-12 1/8 et la part de fondateur à 19 1/2.
L'action Warden Estate a encore gagné 1/8 à 7 1/8; la part de fondateur s'est raffermie à 8 5/8.
Les Héliopolis se sont maintenus à 318, la part de fondateur à 8 3/4. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire out bénéficié de 3 francs à 265- 266 Les Automobiles ont monté à 5 3/8.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont atteint 18 pour revenir en clôture à 17 7/8. Les Egyptian se sont raffer- mis à 6 3/8-7/16. Les Upper Egypt ont pro- gressé à 4 7/8-15/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, il y a eu un bon mouvement sur les Constructions qui, de 1 7/16, ont passé à 1 9/16 pour réactionner aussitôt à 1 1/2. Les parts de fondateur Estates se sont consolidées à 11 1/16 3/4.
Rien de particulier à re'ever sur les autres titres.
A en croire des informations provenant d'Alexandrie, il serait question de la reprise prochaine des négociations tendant à une en- tente entre la Salt and Soda et la Port-Said Salt Association.
On sait que le projet de fusion des deux e Sociétes avait été rejeté par l'assemblée extra- ordinaire da la Port-Said Salt Association tenue à Alexandrie le 21 Avril dernier.
Or, il parait que le projet serait amendé de manière à rendre la fusion acceptable pour les deux parties.

On annonce la prochaine formation de 1' "Egyptian Ritz Hotels Co.", au capital de £150,000. Le premier hôtel de la Société serait construit à Kasr-el-Doubara, sur les ter- rains de la Nile Land and Agricultural Co.

Le comité du Stock Exchange de Londres a décidé d'admettre à la cote officielle la dernière émission de 18,537 "Cumulative Preference Shares", 5 1/2 pour cent, de "Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., de £10 chacune, entière- ment libérées, Nos 85,541 à 104.078.

Les parts de jouissance de la Société des Tramways électriques ont été l'objet d'un fort mouvement à la hausse à Bruxelles dans le cours de la semaine dernière. De 970 francs, sote da 22 Août, elles ont atteint 985 le 24 et 996 25 le 27 Août.
Les recettes des Egyptian Markets pour la semaine au 16 Août dernier se sont chiffrées par L.E. 452 contre 424 pour la période cores- spondante de 1905, soit en augmentation de L.E. 28.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Janvier 1906 se sont élevées à L.E. 23,029 contre 16, 880 en 1905, soit en plus-value de L.E. 6,149 poor l'exercice courant.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs.
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de Esat l'honneur d'informer le Public que, dans le but de prévenir touts contagion de rage, des instructions viennent d'être données à ses agents de tenir la main à le stricte application de l'Art. 81 du Tarif des Voyagenes qui prescrit que les obiens doivent être, durant leur transport, installés dane les fourgone et tacés à moutié prix de la III classe.

Toutefeis si les voyageurs d'un même compartiment sont unanimement d'accord pour tolérer la présence d'un chien avec son proprié tuire, l'Administration n'y objectera pas pourvu quo le prix de son transport ait été régullière-ment payé

The murderous outrage at the house of M. Stolypin, the Russian Premier—which, so far as its intended victim was concerned, was happily a failure—can only awaken horror even among the most earnest sympathizers with the cause of liberty in Russia. M. Stoly- pin, however ineffective his policy may have been, is personally a blameless and amiable figure. He took the Premiership with the intention of offering moderate reforms, and he began by negotiating with leading politicians of the Octobrist party for places in his Cabinet. If these negotiations proved unsuccessful and M. Stolypin's position soon became ambiguous, it is because the hidden forces of reaction are still too strong to be combated by a statesman who holds his mandate not from the people but from the Tsar. ("Times.")

Reaction even in its blackest form would be preferable to the anarchy of the Terror, But the choice need not be, and ought not to be, between these two extremes. The great majority of educated people in Russia are in favour of a Constitutional Monarchy, and would gladly rally to the support of the Grand Dukes and the Court, and call together a real Cabinet of Reform, without neutralising its political complexion, as was done in the case of M. Stolypin's Cabinet, by the inclusion of Ministers purposely chosen to act as a drag on their chief. It looks to outsiders as though the occasion called for common action on the part of the Octobrists and the Cadets or Con- stitutional Democrats who are in general agreement on their broad lines of policy—to prove to the world that the Terrorists are not the only earnest politicians in Russia.
("Telegraph.")

The general attitude of -Frenchmen towards the Church is one of indulgent indifference. On the other hand, they are quietly deter- mined that on no conceivable consideration shall the foundations of the Republic be shaken. The system of government which was based on the ruins of a profligate, cor- rupt, adventurous, and unsettling Empire has given peace and confidence to the nation —has preserved its peace and maintained its confidence through several anxious crises. Unfortunately, some of the men who have distinguished themselves by zeal for the Church are equally well known for their antipathy to the Republic. It was a bad day for Roman Catholicism in France when some of its leaders formed an alliance with the Nationalists, and thus identified its spiritual claims with a disturbing and disloyal movement.
("Standard.")
Whether tipping as a practice is right or wrong, the non-tipper's life is seldom unattend- ed with the sort of trouble to which we refer below :—
A most economical skipper
Owned a craft which he knew was a clipper.
But she won ne'er a race
Till the crew, to his face
Said, "Yoi see, sir, you are not a tipper."
A climber ascending a pass
Belonged to the non-tipping class,
When his guide said "A tip?"
He said, "None of your lip,"
And he's now somewhere in a crevasse.
("Globe.")

Mr. Roosevelt's conversion to the doctrine of the reformed spelling is no new thing. It has grown out of his profound admiration for the works of the late Mr. Artemus Ward, who, as all the world knows, was one of the earliest pioneers of this reform.

We understand that the presidential mandate applies—for the moment, at any rate—to the American language only, but if England does not soon fall into line it will be regarded as a breach of the Monroe doctrine, and, there- fore, as a distinctly unfriendly act.

We also hear, by the way, that the Kaiser, not to be outdone by the second strongest in the world, is shortly issuing a code of rules of English syntax, under which any misuse of the unsplit infinitive will be regarded as lèse majesté, and punishable by ten years' solitary confinement in a military fortress.
("Tribune.")

Few deep thinkers have devoted much atten- tion to the subject of male costume. Centuries ago, a great intellect found that a couple of battons on the back of the coat would keep the sword belt in position. Though none of us habitually wear swords, or even swords belts, with our frock coats, we still retain the buttons invented by the great intellect. Since his death, little was done for us when M. Gibus invented the opera hat. Now, that really was a useful thing. It is astounding, therefore, that we, who have retained the two buttons, should have discarded the opera hat.. Nothing is more disastrous to a silk hat than theatre wear, except, of course, church wear. Why shouldn't we wear opera hats when we go to church? If you saw your solicitor on Sunday wearing his opera hat, you would withdraw your trust moneys from his keeping.
Frank Richardson in the "Pall Mall Gazette.")

div.head: AMERICAN CONSUL-GENERAL'S COMPLAINT.
div.p: The increasing activity of German shipping in the Mediterranean is causing the American Consul General at Marseilles much anxiety.

Until a year ago, he states in a recent report, the German flag was inconspicuous in the Mediterranean. German steamers to the United States and to the Far East called at Italian ports only, principally for passengers and emi- grants. The only important concern then operating from Marseilles was the East African Company, with ships going as far as Durhan (Natal). Since then a complete charge of policy has been adopted, with a consequent feeling of uneasiness among shipowners of other nations, and probably also of irritation in circles acus- tomed to regard as peculiarly their own that large volume of trade handled at Marseilles.

The first visible sign of the German shipping invasion was the establishment of a weekly line of fine and fast North German Lloyd steamers between Marseilles and Alexandria. Next came the announcement of a semi- monthly service organised by the German Levant and North German Lloyd companies between Marseilles Constantinople, Batoim, and intermediate ports.

The North German Lloyd Company has arranged to have its steamers from Australia call at Marseilles every month, thus duplicat- ing present French and British services, and it seems a fair inference, although it is not announced, that the same steamers will call at this port on their journey outward.

Finally, the Hamburg-American Company announces a new monthly service from Mir- seilles to the Persian Golf. Complaint is voiced in France that this sudden accession of interest on the part of German shipowners in this part of the world is not explained by traffis require- ments. At Genoa, numerous German lines call regularly, and it is evident that a ruinous sys- tem is being arranged whereby every region will be connected eventually and made to constitute an efficient feeder for German con- merce, and probably also for the heavy German railway investment in Turkey.

It is scarcely to be presumed, adds the Consul, that old French and British companies, which have worked together fairly well in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, will fail to answer this challenge.

In the recent general assembly of the stock- holders of the Compagnie des Messageries Maritimes, the most important of the French navigation companies, an increase in the capi- tol stock of 30,000,000 francs was authorised for the purpose of adding to the fleet aid to assure its future.

div.head: SCIENCE TAKES THE PLEDGE.
div.p: It is a striking fact that science and morality are now at one in ruling alcohol to be a danger to the human being. Human nature being what it is, the rational arguments which science brings against alcohol are at least as likely to make for temperance as the trascen- dental arguments which religion employs. It has for years been observed by mountain clim- bers that work in the high altitudes, which most severely tries human vitality, it better accomplised by abstainers, and it is, of course, a commonplace that any insurance will give special terms to teetotallers, because their expectation of life is longer than even that of the most moderate drinkers. If alcohol be injurious and poisonous, the abstainer's longer life is explained; while if alcohol be a harmless drag or a valuable food, the insurance results are quite inexplicable.—"Daily Mail."

div.head: A CURIOUS STORY.
div.p: Through an order for the deportation from Canada of an English immigrant classed as a vagrant, a romantic story of a member of an aristocrate British family has come to light. A fine, soldierly appearing man was arrested at Ottawa several days ago accused of begging. He said he was Claude Hamilton and denied the charge. On evidence submitted he was ordered to be deported.

It then was ascertained that the alleged vagrant bad come to the capital with letters of introduction to Colonel Hanbury Williams, military secretary to the Governor General of Canada. He was described in these letters as an English officer who had served in the Soudan under Lord Kitchener and in India. He looked the part to perfection, having the manners and stylish make op of an English officer and with the genuine tan acquired in military service in Egypt and India. He was accompanied to Ottawa by a handsome, well- dressed young English girl, an actress, whom he had married a few days before leaving England. He had ample money for immediate needs when be arrived here, but spent it lavishly.

A remittance, which, be said, should be on its way from England, sufficient to keep him for a year, not having arrived when his last dollar was gone, his baggage was seized at the hotel for an unpaid board bill. He applied at the police station for an order for the recovery of his property and then the story came out. He had been unable to deliver his letters to Colonel Hanbury-Williams and others because they were out of town for the summer vaca- tion. There was a stormy scene in the hotel between Hamilton and his young wife. She ac- cused him of having assured her he was a man of wealth. With their baggage gone, and with- out food or shelter, the man walked the streets until he was arrested. The woman sought and found work as a servant with a family in Mackenzie avenue. (New York Press.)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain Louis B. Cumberland, King's Royal Rifle Corps, who was latterly serving with the 1st Battalion at Cairo, has gone on the retired pay of his rank. He spent nearly 25 years in the K.R.R.C., the last eight in command of a company. He was with the regiment in the Isazai Expedition, 1899 ; the Chitral Expedition, 1895 (medal with clasp), and the South African War, including the defence of Ladysmith, and the ensuing campaign, in the course of which he was severely wounded (Queen's medal with four clasps, King's medal with two clasps).

Major A. M. Pirie, D.S.O., 21st Lancers, who was well known in Egypt both as an officer of that gallant regiment and as an officer of the Khedive's army, has retired from the army on the retired pay of his rank, and at the same time has been appointed to a squadron in the Middlesex Hussars I. Y. Major Pirie's retirement from the "Omdur- man Boys" is much regretted.

The vacant majority in the 20th Hussars has been filled by the promotion of Captain James W. Ferguson, and in turn, the senior subaltern, Lieutenant Carlyle Mac G. Dunbar, just appointed aide-de-camp to Major-General G. M. Bullock, commanding the British troops in Egypt, has been promoted captain. Major Ferguson got his first commission in the 3rd Prince of Wales's Dragoon Guards in April, 1890, was promoted captain in 1898, and exchanged the following year to his present regiment. With the 20th he served in the South African war, 1902, and took part in the operations in Transvaal and Orange River Colony (Queen's medal with four clasps).

Sanction has been given for Lieutenant J.B.M. Matthews-Donaldson, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Cairo, (now at home on leave) being detailed for a tour of duty at the regimental depot, Omagh, in relief of Lieutenant W. A. G. Kinsman, D.S.O., whose tour expires on the 4th prox. The former officer will join at Omagh on the 5th.

Major and Brevet Lieutenant Colonel H.R. Lloyd, Royal Sussex Regiment, second in command of the 2nd Battalion, Crete, has been placed on half pay under the provisions of Article 92 Royal Warrant of this year. Lieutenant Colonel Lloyd became connected with the Royal Sussex Regiment in February, 1904, when he was specialty transferred from the Somersetshire Light Infantry as second in command of his late battalion. He got his first commission in the Somersets to far back as August, 1878, and kit advancement was very slow. He saw service with the Somersets in the Burmese Expedition, 1885-87 (medal with clasp), and in South Africa he had a varied experience in the Transvaal, Orange River Colony and Cape Colony, and for nearly a year commanded his battalion in the field, although then only a major of three years' standing. For his services he was twice men- tioned in despatches, given a brevet lieutenant colmelcy, and the Queen's medal with three clasps, and the King's medal with two clasps.

Some time ago considerable consternation was caused by the statement that a large per- centage of the navy's guns were almost useless owing to defective sights, and the case of first class battleship Centurion, sent out to the China Station, was instanced as one of the most glaring. Since then the matter was taken up by the Admiralty, and under the superin- tendence of Captain Jellicoe, the Director of Naval Ordnance, the re-sighting of the older pattern guns on the active list has been success- fully carried ont. The process has been a very costly one, as the cross sighting apparatus, with its complicated series of dials and tele- scopes costs from £120 in the 6 inch gun to £200 in the 12 inch. The night sighting has not yet been completed, but it is well in hand. That the sighting should have been allowed to deviate so much from the true until it became notorious is one of the things not easy to understand.

Captain A. G. Macdonald, Royal Berkshire Regiment, having completed his tenure in the adjutancy of the 1st Battalion at Dublin, has been succeeded by Lieutenant Herbert L. Stevens, of the same battalion. The new adjutant of the 49th joined the regiment in May, 1900, from the ranks of the Natal Forces in the field, and he has had considerable service on the staff and in the field. He shared in the Matabeleland campaign, 1893 (medal) and was with the Natal Mounted Polios in the South African War, 1889-1900, including the fighting for the relief of Ladysmith (Queen's medal w ith two clasps). and after getting hit commis- sion he was employed for some time with the West African Frontier Force, was aide de camp to the Governor of the Gold Coast, and up till a year ago was employed in the East African Protectorate.

div.head: CRICKET.
E.T.C. SUEZ v. C.S. ELECTRA AND SHERAD OSBORN.
div.p: A match between the above teams was play- ed at Suez last Saturday. The ship's team, which batted first, were dismissed by Mansell and Battiscombe, assisted by a certain element of luck, for the small total of 68. The E.T.C. started badly and lost 7 wickets for 53, but thanks to some free hitting by Shaddock and steady batting of Mansell and Harris, even- tually won an exciting game by 24 runs. For the visitors Kendall and Pickthall did well both in batting and bowling. Scores :—
C.S. Electra and Sherard Osborn.

div.head: R.I.C.C.
div.p: The Institute did not do so well as usual last month, despite the fact that the team was stronger than it had been for some time. It is true that they encountered better sides than usual, but this is no excuse for the poor displays they have given. Want of proper practice had a lot to do with this. We may look for a better state of things now that Rev J.T. Burns is back, and it is to be hoped that the R.I.C.C. will add to their list of victories this month.

On Friday, 27th July, the Institute gained an unexpected victory over the Army Ordnanoe Corps. The home team occupied the wickets first but were soon out for 50. The visitors did even worse, the whole side being out for 35. R. Appleby bowled extremely well, his six wickets costing him only 8 runs.

The Institute were badly beaten on Friday, 3rd August, by "F" Company, King's Royal Rifles. They batted first and completely collapsed, the total only amounting to 29. This the soldiers easily passed and eventually won by 61 runs.
On Friday, 10th August, the Institute visit- ed Slade Park and were defeated by the Mounted Military Police. Bad fielding was mainly responsible for this loss.

On Friday, 17th August, the Institute were beaten for the third time in succession. The Detachment of the Berks. Regiment completely outplayed the homesters and after scoring 106 disposed of the Institute for 50. At one time it seemed as if 20 would not be reached, no fewer then six wickets falling for 6 runs. G. Attwood was top scorer with a nicely compil- ed 22.
The record of matches played this season is :—
Played 19 ; Won 10 ; Lost 7 , Drawn 2.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du public qu'elle dispose de quinze postes d'apprentis vacants au service de la comptabi- lité et du contrôle.
Un examen aura lieu à cet effet au Bureau Central de la comptabilité le 14 Septembre courant à 9 h. a.m.
Les candidats qui seront choisis seront payés à raison de L.E. 3 par mois. Après six mois d'essai et s'ils donnent satisfaction, cette paie sera augmentée suivant leurs mérites.
Toute demande doit être accompagnée d'une feuille timbrée de P.T. 3 et adressée avant le 14 Septembre courant:
A Mr. le Controleur Général de la Compta- bilité des Chemins de fer de l'Etat, au Caire.
Les candidats devront joindre à leurs de- mandes:
1. Un certificat de nationalité égyptienne.
2. Un certificat de naissance constatant qu'ils ne sont pas âgés de plus de 22 ans ni moins de 18 ans.
3. Le certificat études primaires émanant du Ministère de l'Instruction Publique et non antérieur à 1903.
4. Leur avis de licenciement s'ils ont déjà été au service du Gouvernement.
5. Un certificat de bonne vie et moeurs.
Le Caire, le 1er Septembre 1906. 28,431-2-1

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria ,Damanhour, Tantah, Zagazig, or Saida Zenab.
